result.execSummary:
The defendant Jordan Michael Effert was found guilty of the following charge(s) in this case.

  • Disorderly Conduct, a class B misdemeanor, Wisconsin Statutes 947.01(1).

Notice to employers: It may be a violation of state law to discriminate against a job applicant because of an arrest or conviction record. Generally speaking, an employer may refuse to hire an applicant on the basis of a conviction only if the circumstances of the conviction substantially relate to the particular job. For more information, see Wisconsin Statute 111.335 and the Department of Workforce Development's publication, Arrest and Conviction Records under the Law.

supervisions.notes: All financial obligations to be paid at the rate of $50/month commencing 10-1-15 or serve 14 days jail and civil judgment to be entered.

Defendant may write the Court in one year requesting expungement upon completion of the following conditions:
1.  No problems/convictions of any kind.
2.  Obtain GED
3.  Go back to Dr. and take all medications as prescribed and provide letter from the Dr. in one year indicating compliance.
4.  Pay fine in full.

judgments.action: Guilty Due to No Contest Plea

charges.dispoDesc: Guilty Due to No Contest Plea

result.caption: State of Wisconsin vs. Jordan Michael Effert

records.descr: Records of prosec. are converted data. See file.

Court imposes:  Fine $100 + costs = $379.00 pay $50/month commencing 10-1-15 or serve 14 days jail and judgment.
Court grants expungement.  Defendant to send letter in one year requesting expungment upon completion of the following four conditions:
1.  No further problems with the law or convictions of any kind.
2.  Obtain GED
3.  Go back to Dr. and take all medications as directed.  Provide letter from Dr. indicating compliance.
4.  Pay fine in full.
